bibl.title: Dispatch from William M. Davis to Hilary R. W. Johnson, January 23, 1891
Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

body.div1:
His Execellency H.V.W. Johnson
Mr. President, When I arrived in the United States, on thr 14th September 1890 I found the country in a great state of excitement consequent on the elections, which were held on the 4th of November last.
I found it would be useless to go on to Washington then, as Mr. Seemtale* my Blaine was away on an elections were over which resulted disastorialy* for the present Administration in nearly all the States divert to Washington, on the 10th of Novembe, and the next day, Now John U. Smith, with whom I stopped while in the city, accompanied me to the State Department, when we found twenty or more persons, all waiting to get our
interview
interview with the Secretary. We waited about half a day, and were then informed that the Secretary would not be at his office that day, Mr. Smith and I called the next day, but after waiting some hours he had to leave, but I remained and about 1 o'clock thr Secretary came, and I was admitted to an interview for about tem mintues. Mr. Blaine then excused himself as the new Spanish Minister was thn waiting by appointment to be taken to the White House to be presented to the President. Mr. Seemtary asked me to call on him the next day, and instructed the usher to bring me "right in", as soon as he sat to the office. I called the next Saturday but after waiting until after 12m. was told, to the great disappointment of all of us then waiting, that the Seemtary **invade not be at his office that day.
I called at the Department the next Monday and Tuesday; but with the same. One of the gentlemen that I met waiting to see the Secretary, told
me
me that he had called daily for fourteen days, ad when I left, he had not got been favored with an interview.
I then left Washington, and from Philadelphia I wrote a letter to Secretary Blaine, copy of which I now present. After waiting several days without an answer, I wrote Mr. Cappinger and requested him to call upon the Secretary and inquired whether my letter had been shown to him, and feared that it might be laid down somewhere and not come under his notice. Mr. Cappinger wrote me that he had called several times at the Department, but without success, but that he would still try to carry out my wishes
Mr. Blaine received me very courteously, and but for the poet that the Spanish Minister by his appointment, I think he would have given me a much longer and favorable interview. I requested the Secretary to send me an answer to
New York
New York, and prehaps I may get it by next mail.
This matter having been initated allowed me to suggest, Mr. President , that it be followed up through thr State Department, as I deem it of great importance, at this time, that we have a demonstration of friendship from one of the Great Powers I have the honor to be Mr. President
Your obident Servant W.M.Davis Commissioner
A true copy from the original on file in the State Department
Wilson C. Slev. State Dept
